Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Rich,
> I don't have a lot of personal experience with Akao work, but my
> understanding is that the later generations did some work in iron,
> although not as much. Also, while the first two generations started
> working in copper alloy after leaving Echizen, I don't think that they
> stopped making iron tsuba. FWIW, I have an iron sukashi guard signed
> Kofu ju Akao Yoshitsugu. This would probably be the third generation
> or later. Your kanji for the nidai signature did not come out for
> me. Sorting out generations from the signatures without personal
> names is not straightforward.
>
> Jim
>
>
> All, does anyone know if the Akao smith Yoshitsugu ( Shodai and Nidai )
> was the only smith of this group ( 9 generations I think ) that worked
> in tetsu ?. I see the 1st and the 2nd Yoshitsugu worked in Shakudo
> Sukashi after they moved to Edo, but worked in iron whilst in Echizen.
> Did any of the other 7 Yoshitsugu's work in Iron, or were they all in
> Shakudo and Shibuichi plate.
>
> Also, I see the Nidai signed ???? ( Akao Yoshitsugu if the kanji does
> not come out ), did any other of the group sign this way ?.
>
> Cheers
>
> Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akao tsuba smith's and their work.
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I don t have a lot of personal experience with Akao work, but my understanding is that the later generations did some work in iron, although not as much.
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I don't have a lot of personal experience with Akao work, but my understanding is that the later generations did some work in iron, although not as much. Also, while the first two generations started working in copper alloy after leaving Echizen, I don't think that they stopped making iron tsuba. FWIW, I have an iron sukashi guard signed Kofu ju Akao Yoshitsugu. This would probably be the third generation or later. Your kanji for the nidai signature did not come out for me. Sorting out generations from the signatures without personal names is not straightforward.

Jim


All, does anyone know if the Akao smith Yoshitsugu ( Shodai and Nidai )
was the only smith of this group ( 9 generations I think ) that worked
in tetsu ?. I see the 1st and the 2nd Yoshitsugu worked in Shakudo
Sukashi after they moved to Edo, but worked in iron whilst in Echizen.
Did any of the other 7 Yoshitsugu's work in Iron, or were they all in
Shakudo and Shibuichi plate.

Also, I see the Nidai signed ???? ( Akao Yoshitsugu if the kanji does
not come out ), did any other of the group sign this way ?.

Cheers

Rich Turner



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Akao tsuba smith's and their work.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard; The hitsu ana are of the Jingo style but not quite as elegant as Jingo work if you know what I mean.  The iron and plate do not seem to be Jingo to
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard;

The hitsu ana are of the Jingo style but not quite as elegant as Jingo work if you know what I mean. The iron and plate do not seem to be Jingo to me from the photos. I have one very similar that is signed. I will see if I can dig it up and send you a picture.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, April 26, 2005 7:35 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Akao tsuba smith's and their work.



Just picked this up, I am assuming ( a dangerous thing in any game )
this is the shodai or nidai Yoshitsugu as I can find no reference of
any of the other 5 doing Iron work ?. any thoughts on the contrary ?,
or a confirmation of my assumptions ?.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yoshitsugu_01.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yoshitsugu_02.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yoshitsugu_03.jpg

Also, I picked this up, any thought's on a school here, maybe a
country piece ?.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba_01.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba_02.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba_03.jpg

manyh thanks

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Han Bing Siong book now in stock
messages.msgSnippet: Hi; This is a very nice book and I recommend it to the sword enthusiast. John ... From: Craig L. Harris To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, April
messages.messageBody:
Hi;

This is a very nice book and I recommend it to the sword enthusiast.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Craig L. Harris
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 25, 2005 10:58 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Han Bing Siong book now in stock


I am pleased to announce that "Japanese Swords in Dutch Collections," the
2003 publication of the late Mr. Han Bing Siong by the Netherlands Token
Society, is now in stock.

Though I have over the years read and admired Mr. Han's articles in the
JSS/US Newsletter, English Token Bijitsu, and elsewhere, spending some time
with this book has overwhelmed me with the extent of his scholarship and the
magnitude of our loss with his recent passing.

As the former owner of a katana signed (gimei, of course!) Hankei, I read
with interest the first entry in the book, a wakizashi by Hankei. I felt
like I learned more from that two pages than I had in all the reading I had
done back when I owned that blade and dug up every article, oshigata, and
reference to Hankei that I could find.

This is the kind of book that makes me proud to be a bookseller.


SIONG, HAN BING. Japanese Swords in Dutch Collections A Selection from 500
Descriptions in the Series Japanse Zwaarden in Nederland Bezit. Rijswijk,
Netherlands: The Netherlands Token Society, 2003. First edition. 244 p.
Translated from the Dutch by J. M. Bonsel and M. Laros. This selection of
85 blades of the 500 cataloged by Han Bing Song since 1979 was published to
celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Netherlands Token Society. The
cataloging project included swords in museums as well as private
collections. Of those presented in this book, a range of swords from Koto
through Gendaito are shown with oshigata and Mr. Han's scholarly and
insightful comments. Seventeen of the blades are also presented in
photographs, and there are 14 pages of full color photographs of the best of
the koshirae. An outstanding publication of the highest quality and most
valuable content. Pictorial Hardcover. As New. $100.00

Shipping:
U.S. Media Mail (4-14 days) $ 4.00
U.S. Priority Mail (2-4 days) $12.00
Canada Air Parcel Post (4-10 days) $18.00
Canada Global Priority (4-6 days) $20.00

Rates for other destinations gladly quoted on request.

Visa, MasterCard, Discover, PayPal. Illinois Residents must add 8.50% Sales
Tax.


Craig L. Harris Bridge of Dreams, LLC
Books from and about Asia o: 847 696-9774
www.bridgeofdreams.com c: 847-846-7701

b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:

messages.subject: Akao tsuba smith's and their work.
messages.msgSnippet: All, does anyone know if the Akao smith Yoshitsugu ( Shodai and Nidai ) was the only smith of this group ( 9 generations I think ) that worked in tetsu ?. I
messages.messageBody:
All, does anyone know if the Akao smith Yoshitsugu ( Shodai and Nidai )
was the only smith of this group ( 9 generations I think ) that worked
in tetsu ?. I see the 1st and the 2nd Yoshitsugu worked in Shakudo
Sukashi after they moved to Edo, but worked in iron whilst in Echizen.
Did any of the other 7 Yoshitsugu's work in Iron, or were they all in
Shakudo and Shibuichi plate.

Also, I see the Nidai signed ???? ( Akao Yoshitsugu if the kanji does
not come out ), did any other of the group sign this way ?.

Cheers

Rich Turner
